Chief Executive's Fire Safety Statement
Chief Executive

1.2.1 The Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order became law on the 1st October 2006, replacing 118 pieces of legislation, repealing the Fire Precautions Act  and revoking The Fire Precautions (Workplace) Regulations. At a stroke, all fire certificates and plans were replaced by a system of risk-based assessment, whereby accountability lies squarely and firmly with 'the responsible person' in any business and they will be held accountable under the new legislation.

1.2.2 Serious fires in Hospitals are rare but a risk of injury by fire or smoke exists. Effective implementation of this Fire Safety Policy and the underpinning fire safety procedures, by all Staff at every level will ensure compliance with the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005 (The Order) and assist to reduce the risk of harm arising from fire or smoke.

1.2.3 In the event of smoke or fire event our primary challenge is to ensure the safety of ambulant, semi-ambulant and non-ambulant occupants whilst maintaining basic clinical needs. Compliance with this policy by all Staff aims to ensure the priority of life over property at all times.

1.2.4 The Trust recognises that creating and sustaining a fire safety aware workforce, maintaining fire detection and suppression systems, and reducing unwanted false fire alarms is critical to our continued fire prevention success. The Trust will work together with all employees, sub-contractors employed or sharing Trust premises, Essex County Fire & Rescue Service, Building Control and other agencies to ensure fire compliance, and to foster a positive fire safety culture demonstrating our commitment to valuing people and the safety of their environment.

This Fire Safety Policy and Procedure aims to minimise risk of fire and smoke events in Mid-Essex Hospitals Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon & Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust property and other places where Trust staff are contracted to work. This is achieved by embracing efficient fire safety prevention procedures, developing quality control measures to reduce risks by effectively containing and extinguishing fires and avoiding unwanted false fire alarm calls. The Trust is committed to ensure priority of life over that of property is demonstrated at all times. This policy document details the structure of the organisation's management of fire safety and includes references to fire related procedural documents.

The Trust key objective is to minimise risk of personal injury from fire or smoke by conducting fire risk assessments in compliance with the Order, and by providing adequate and audited staff fire training, evacuation drills, inspection of premises, as well as by installation and maintenance of fire detection and suppression systems and provision of CCTV (as a means of fire investigation and arson deterrent).

The Trust will ensure maintenance of buildings, fire response equipment, completion and audit of associated records, identification of unwanted fire alarms and seek to identify potential hazards and reduce fire risk in respect of all buildings.

Trust Board

The Trust Board must ensure that risk management and assurance monitoring is undertaken to maintain the safety of employees and other relevant persons at all times. They are responsible for implementation of such general fire safety precautions to make premises and the persons therein safe. This is achieved by monitoring reports and compliance or non-compliance letters received from Essex Fire and Rescue service. The Board also receives regular summaries from the fire assurance reports.
4.1.1 Health and Safety Committee
Review, approve and endorse this policy;
Reviewing the document content for accuracy;
Considering the effectiveness of the policy in terms of achieving its purpose;
All fire safety matters are kept under review including risk assessments and action in respect of any recommendation.
4.1.2 Estates and Facilities Fire Group

This Group meets on a bi-monthly basis at each Trust and its objective is to gain assurance that the management and delivery of the fire safety agenda against agreed objectives and NHS Fire code HTM 05-01 is effective and efficient. The Committee is responsible for:
Planning and reviewing the sequencing of building fire risk assessments and follow on activities, progress ownership by departments and Estates, corrective action planning and follow-up;
To review condition and engineering surveys, in accordance with risk management techniques: are risk rated in terms of those that exist and are current and those that are outstanding;
To agree an investment strategy for present and future requirements in order to facilitate the effective management of fire safety;

To review maintenance routines and testing regimes and ensure that these are recorded and scheduled within the Trust CAFM (or similar) management system. In addition, to identify fire related data which may not be formally recorded or which is held on other systems;
To receive management reports so that the group can review performance against standards;

To develop the standard, and procedures for, the management of fire safety in line with the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005 main duties ‘general fire precautions', identifying responsible person, ensuring procedures, policies and instructions are valid and current;
To review Trust fire policies and evacuation plans;

To develop fire safety specifications and contribute to the work of the capital planning team in order to ensure that those involved in refurbishments and construction projects can access professional expertise and standard specifications for fire safety within the Trust estate;

To monitor the reports on fire incidents and review the actions taken to mitigate recurrence, and to promote the best practice protocols which may be developed following investigatory review of fire incidents;
To review operational issues associated with the delivery of a safe estate for
use by staff, patients, residents and visitors.
Chief Executive has overall responsibility for fire safety in all premises owned or occupied by the Trust which involves ensuring:

Current legal requirements are met and, where appropriate, best practice HTM guidance is implemented (noting that HTM guidance presents one method of managing fire safety and recognises that there may be other ways to manage fire safety effectively);
Appropriate programmes of work to improve and maintain fire safety within the organisation's premises;
Sufficient resources are allocated to meet fire safety compliance requirements in both existing buildings and new constructions;

Nominating a Board level Director to act as the responsible person accountable to the Chief Executive for line management of all fire safety activities and monitoring the effectiveness of this policy.

data.text: Auditing

7.2.1 Audits for the purposes of compiling fire risk assessments as required by the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005 and those for monitoring compliance differ. Risk assessment aims first to identify the fire hazards and the particular risks these may present to the occupants of a healthcare facility.

7.2.2 Following assessment of the risks, effective fire precautions are arranged to reduce the risk as far as reasonably practicable. A compliance fire safety audit aims to verify that these fire precautions, once in place, are being maintained effectively.

7.2.3 For the purposes of monitoring compliance a fire safety audit will examine and question all aspects of fire safety and will be carried out by the Estates & Facilities Compliance Team, The Estates & Facilities Quality Team or an Authorising Engineer (Fire). Current fire safety management procedures, including maintenance procedures and procedures for alerting the fire-and-rescue service in the event of a fire in accordance with Health Technical Memorandum 05-03 Part B – ‘Fire detection and alarm systems'.
Any changes in the use of premises necessitating re assessment of risks;
Effectiveness of communication systems, including fire alarm and detection systems;
Adequacy of local fire safety instructions and procedural documents;
Standard of incident management and related records-keeping;
Adequacy of training and related record-keeping;
Completion of action following risk assessment;
Management of occupied and unoccupied buildings
Monitoring of compliance with statutory requirements;
Identification of weaknesses in compliance;
Setting up of remedial programmes;
A rolling programme for installing and maintaining an adequate level of fire precautions;
Sufficiency of resources within the framework of business plans to implement recommendations arising from risk assessments.
7.2.4 The audit will be systematic and cover all aspects of fire safety including physical precautions, staffing arrangements and management systems.
7.2.5 Where required, validation checks should be included in the audits. For example:
Details of evidence supporting acceptance of responsibilities for fire safety, as set out in this policy;
Details of inspections of visual integrity of cavity barriers, and other fire stopping arrangements should be verified;
Testing and recording the condition and effectiveness of fire alarm ,detection and extinguishment systems;
Checking and recording the condition of first-aid fire-fighting equipment;
Checking the effectiveness of escape lighting and the presence of fire drawings, in signing the means of escape, or other physical fire precautions such as door shutting to create a compartment;
Procedures for issuing “hot work” permits, and the control and use of flammable materials (for example adhesives) within healthcare premises;
Relevant consultation with local fire and building control authorities;
Correct procedures for the storage of flammable liquids;
Practice of evacuation techniques involving the use of escape bed lifts (provided in accordance with Health Technical Memorandum 05-03 Part E – ‘Escape lifts in healthcare premises')
Provisions for commercial premises (see Health Technical Memorandum 05- 03: Part D – ‘Commercial enterprises on healthcare premises')
Fire safety in staff residences (houses in multiple occupation)
Policies for purchasing flame-retardant textiles and furniture (Health Technical Memorandum 05-03 Part C).
7.2.6 The findings of the audit specifying details of fire prevention remedial actions, considered necessary should be presented to the Trust Board by the Fire Safety Director.
